how_to_use.use_case_en: IV infusion pumps have largely replaced this calculation in many healthcare settings, however in resource scarce settings, this is how one can calculate an infusion rate by just counting drops per minute and adjusting accordingly.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: It is critical to know your drop factor; typically IV infusion tubing will include this information on its label or packaging.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Some medications must be given at a certain rate due to toxicity or side effects from infusing too quickly; other medications are vasoactive and require a constant infusion and titration in order to work correctly.

next_steps.critical_actions_en: It is critical to know your drop factor; typically IV infusion tubing will include this information on its label or packaging.

about.formula_en:
IV Drip Rate, gtts/min = (Volume to be given, mL x Drop factor*, gtts/mL) / Time, min

*Common drop factors for IV tubing sets:

60 gtts/mL minidrip drip set

10 gtts/mL regular drip set

15 gtts/mL regular drip set

20 gtts/mL regular drip set

Original/Primary Reference.text: Gage CB, Toney-Butler TJ. Dose Calculation. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing. 2020.

expert_name.description: Graham Walker, MD, is an emergency physician practicing in San Francisco, California. Dr. Walker attended medical school at the Stanford University School of Medicine and then trained in emergency medicine at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York City, where he was Chief Resident. He returned to the west coast as a Medical Simulation fellow and attending in Stanford’s emergency department. More relevant, of course, is that Dr. Walker is the creator and developer of MDCalc and remains active in content and calculator development, along with our many other endeavors as President of MD Aware, LLC (MDCalc’s parent company).
